references:
Theorem 3.1 shows that the averaged sequence generated by Local SGD has an asymptotic normal distribution with the asymptotic variance depending on how communication happens (i.e., the sequence {Em}subscript𝐸𝑚\{E_{m}\}) and the problem parameters (i.e., 𝑺𝑺\bm{S} and 𝑮𝑮\bm{G}).
For one thing, the effect of data heterogeneity doesn’t show up in the asymptotic normality.
The asymptotic variance as well as L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} convergence rate is the same with that of P-SGD.
This is because the residual error caused by data heterogeneity typically has relatively low order than the statistical error incurred by stochastic gradients (Woodworth et al., 2020b, a).
With the choice of γmsubscript𝛾𝑚\gamma_{m}, the residual error vanishes much faster and then seems to disappear.
For another thing, it is quite interesting that the whole optimization process affects the asymptotic variance.
At the worst case, the way how communication frequency is determined only enlarges the asymptotic variance by a known scale ν(≥1)annotated𝜈absent1\nu(\geq 1).
If Em≡1subscript𝐸𝑚1E_{m}\equiv 1 for all m𝑚m (which implies no local update is called), ν=1𝜈1\nu=1 and the result is identical to the typical single-machine central limit theorem (CLT) for SGD (Polyak and Juditsky, 1992).
When Emsubscript𝐸𝑚E_{m} varies, it is still possible to get communication saved and the asymptotic variance unchanged (i.e., ν=1𝜈1\nu=1) simultaneously (see Table 1).
If Emsubscript𝐸𝑚E_{m} is uniformly bounded or grows in a rate slower than E​lnβ⁡m​(β>0)𝐸superscript𝛽𝑚𝛽0E\ln^{\beta}m(\beta>0), we maintain ν=1𝜈1\nu=1 and obtain a smaller average communication frequency (ACF).
In the latter case, the ACF is asymptotic zero, which implies that we trade almost all computation for nearly zero communication without any sacrifice for statistical efficiency.
However, if Emsubscript𝐸𝑚E_{m} grows like E​mβ​(β∈(0,1))𝐸superscript𝑚𝛽𝛽01Em^{\beta}\ (\beta\in(0,1)), though its ACF decays much more rapidly than that of E​lnβ⁡m𝐸superscript𝛽𝑚E\ln^{\beta}m, the asymptotic variance is increased by a factor of ν=(1−β2)−1𝜈superscript1superscript𝛽21\nu=(1-\beta^{2})^{-1}.
It depicts a trade-off between communication efficiency and statistical efficiency when Emsubscript𝐸𝑚E_{m} grows too fast.
Finally, Emsubscript𝐸𝑚E_{m} could not grows like E​mβ​(β>1)𝐸superscript𝑚𝛽𝛽1Em^{\beta}\ (\beta>1) or even exponentially fast, because this will violate the requirement ∑m=0T−1Em−1→∞→superscriptsubscript𝑚0𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑚1\sum_{m=0}^{T-1}E_{m}^{-1}\to\infty that is inherent from Assumption 3.4.

When E=1𝐸1E=1, it reduces to the single-machine result that is recently obtained by Lee et al. (2021).
Once E>1𝐸1E>1, an interesting observation is that local updates reduce the scale of the Brown motion.
As an extreme case, the scale vanishes and the Brown motion degenerates when E=∞𝐸E=\infty.
It makes sense because when E=∞𝐸E=\infty, 𝒙tmk≡𝒙k∗superscriptsubscript𝒙subscript𝑡𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘{\bm{x}}_{t_{m}}^{k}\equiv{\bm{x}}_{k}^{*} and 𝒙¯tm≡∑k=1Kpk​𝒙tmksubscript¯𝒙subscript𝑡𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙subscript𝑡𝑚𝑘\bar{\bm{x}}_{t_{m}}\equiv\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}{\bm{x}}_{t_{m}}^{k}, the process degenerates.
Beyond constant Em≡Esubscript𝐸𝑚𝐸E_{m}\equiv E, Theorem 4.2 also embraces mildly increasing {Em}subscript𝐸𝑚\{E_{m}\} (see Table 1).

With this gβ​(⋅)subscript𝑔𝛽⋅g_{\beta}(\cdot), we denote the random variable given in (7) by t∗​(β)superscript𝑡𝛽t^{*}(\beta) and the corresponding critical value by qα,β:=min⁡{t:ℙ​(t∗​(β)≤t)≥1−α}assignsubscript𝑞𝛼𝛽:𝑡ℙsuperscript𝑡𝛽𝑡1𝛼q_{\alpha,\beta}:=\min\{t:{\mathbb{P}}(t^{*}(\beta)\leq t)\geq 1-\alpha\}.
The limiting distribution t∗​(β)superscript𝑡𝛽t^{*}(\beta) is mixed normal and symmetric around zero.
For easy reference, critical values of t∗​(β)superscript𝑡𝛽t^{*}(\beta) are computed via simulations and listed in Table 2.
In particular, the Brownian motion B1​(⋅)subscript𝐵1⋅B_{1}(\cdot) is approximated by normalized sums of i.i.d. 𝒩​(0,1)𝒩01{\mathcal{N}}(0,1) pseudo random deviates using 1,000 steps and 50,000 replications.
We then smooth the 50,000 realizations by standard Gaussian-kernels techniques with the bandwidth selected according to Scott’s rule (Scott, 2015).
Kernel density estimation is a way to estimate the probability density function of a random variable in a non-parametric way.
Because we smooth the data, our critical values of the case β=0𝛽0\beta=0 are slightly different from previous computations by Kiefer et al. (2000).
In particular, when 1−α=97.5%1𝛼percent97.51-\alpha=97.5\% and β=0𝛽0\beta=0, our critical value 6.7536.7536.753 is smaller than previous 6.8116.8116.811, which shrinks the length of our confidence intervals.

We then turn to the empirical performance of Local SGD with limited computation or finite samples.
Table 3 shows the empirical performance of the five methods under linear models with four different tTsubscript𝑡𝑇t_{T}’s.
tTsubscript𝑡𝑇t_{T} is actually the total iteration each client runs through T𝑇T rounds or equivalently the number of observations they receive.
From the table, all the methods achieve good performance.
The random scaling gives better average coverage rates than the plug-in method, because its average coverage rates of all different communication intervals are near (or even exceed) 95%percent9595\%.
However, its average length is usually larger than that of plug-in.
Furthermore, its average length usually has a much larger deviation than that of plug-in.
For example, when tT=5000subscript𝑡𝑇5000t_{T}=5000, for C5, the standard deviation of average lengths for plug-in is 0.807×10−20.807superscript1020.807\times 10^{-2}, while it increases to 3.714×10−23.714superscript1023.714\times 10^{-2} for random scaling.
Such a wider average length might account for the unexpected advantage on the average coverage rates.
However, as the communication round increases and more observations are available, both the average length and its deviations decrease.

In addition, comparing the results of Log, P(1/3), and P(1/2), we can find that the faster Emsubscript𝐸𝑚E_{m} increases, the larger average length as well as its standard deviations. However, they all have satisfactory performance when observations are sufficient.
Indeed, Local SGD trades more computation for less communication, resulting in a residual error gradually accumulated when communication is off, slowing down the convergence rate and enlarging asymptotic variance (e.g., the existence of ν𝜈\nu).
However, the benefit is also attractive: the averaged communication frequency is substantially reduced and the convergence in terms of communication largely increases.
It implies that Local SGD obtains both statistical efficiency and communication efficiency as expected.
We further consider the logistic regression, which is a standard non-linear model.
The result is given in Table 4.
A similar pattern is observed: random scaling has higher average coverage rates at the price of wider average lengths which typically shrink as more observations are generated.
